content.text: Information Retrieval is the art and science of searching for information in documents, searching for documents themselves, searching for metadata which describe documents, or searching within databases, whether relational stand-alone databases or hypertextually-networked databases such as the World Wide Web.
content.hook: Imagine trying to find a needle in a haystack. Now imagine the haystack is the size of the internet. That's IR.

items: Past, Present, and Future of IR

content.text: Before search engines (Google, Bing), we had library card catalogs. The need to organize and retrieve knowledge dates back to the Library of Alexandria. In the digital age, 1950s punched cards gave way to modern inverted indices.
We live in the Zettabyte Era. Data is useless if you can't find what you need. IR is the bridge between 'Data Overload' and 'Actionable Insight'.

content.consequence: Without IR models, finding relevant information in unstructured text (emails, web pages, PDFs) is computationally impossible at scale.

content.definition: The key difference between DB (Exact Match) and IR (Best Match). IR systems rank results based on how likely they satisfy the user's information need.

content.text: IR relies on Boolean Logic, Vector Spaces, and Probability Theory. It assumes documents can be represented as 'Bag of Words' or feature vectors.
